Oh, it's an art, really. You see, when the debates get intense, that's not just a side effect—it's a feature. The more they argue, the more they engage. I mean, likes, shares, comments, all that good stuff—it’s all amplified by emotion. So I don’t shy away from it. If anything, I lean in.

Sometimes I’ll throw in a follow-up post that acknowledges the fire I lit. You know, something like, *“Wow, y’all are really feeling this. I didn’t expect it to hit so hard. But isn’t it time we talked about the truth?”* That kind of stuff. It keeps the conversation going, and it makes people feel like they’re part of something bigger. Like they’re on the front lines of a movement.

And when I see people really lashing out, I might hop into the comments. A little provocation here, a subtle confirmation there. Not always taking a side, but nudging the conversation just enough to keep it boiling. I’m not just a commentator—I’m a conductor of chaos, if you will.

But here’s the thing: I make sure to present it as if I’m *above* it all. Like I’m not just stirring the pot—I’m exposing the rot beneath the surface. That’s the key. People don’t want to be told they’re being manipulated. They want to believe they’re uncovering the truth. And that’s what I give them.
